I haven't bought this book yet:
 Ken's Guide to the Bible 
 but I most likely will.
 
 Reading the first few pages makes it worth the $7.
 
 But I did find a list of "embarrassing questions" from the book.
 
 Would any Christians like to take these on?
 
 1. Do you really believe that Noah was 500 years old when he fathered his first child? (Gen 5:32)
 
 2. Why was it ok for God to destroy the sinful city of Sodom, but not ok to destroy Lot's daughters when they have sex with him? (Gen 19:30-36)
 
 3. Do you really believe that anyone who works on the sabbath should be killed? (Exodus 31:15)
 
 4. Do you believe that children should be put to death for the sins of their parents? (2 Samuel 2:2-4, 14-27; 12:9-19)
 
 5. How come God rewarded Abraham and Lot with earthkly riches but Jesus said that wealth is a one way ticket to hell? (Gen 24:34-35; Job 42:10-12; Matt 19:24)
 
 6. Do you believe in slavery? Then why do the apostles Paul and Peter encourage slaves to be obedient? (Eph 6:5-7; Peter 3:18)
 
 Enjoy.

1. Do you really believe that Noah was 500 years old when he fathered his first child? (Gen 5:32)

 if the bible said so, why wouldnt it be true?
 
2. Why was it ok for God to destroy the sinful city of Sodom, but not ok to destroy Lot's daughters when they have sex with him? (Gen 19:30-36)

 actually, the children of the daughters of lot (the moabites and the ammonites), were cursed by God. later the nation of israel were ordered by God to completely wipe out these tribes
 
3. Do you really believe that anyone who works on the sabbath should be killed? (Exodus 31:15)

 the commandment is actually to keep the sabbath holy. doing good on the sabbath, even if it involves labor, was in accordance with the the commandment
 
4. Do you believe that children should be put to death for the sins of their parents? (2 Samuel 2:2-4, 14-27; 12:9-19)

 well they were, because of the belief in generational curses. it stems from the concept of the original sin. since adam and eve disobeyed God, the sin of disobedience is inherited through all people. following this logic, if your dad was an idolator, that sin would also be in his children, and so on for that entire lineage, so they had to be cut off.
 
5. How come God rewarded Abraham and Lot with earthkly riches but Jesus said that wealth is a one way ticket to hell? (Gen 24:34-35; Job 42:10-12; Matt 19:24)

 jesus never said that riches is a one way ticket to hell. he said it is extremely difficuklt for the rich to enter heaven, but not that riches are evil
 
6. Do you believe in slavery? Then why do the apostles Paul and Peter encourage slaves to be obedient? (Eph 6:5-7; Peter 3:18)

 a "slave" in the context was a "bondservant", which was someone that either owed a debt and had to pay it back in work, or a person that offered to serve another out of obligation or gratitude or whatever the reason. this could also refer to any type of internship or apprentice relationship. it didnt mean that people didnt work for salaries back then.
 
 the borrower is slave to the lender. true now as it was then

 First, there's two issues at hand: The first is punishment for sin in the Old and New Testaments, and the second issue is whether moral guidelines have changed.

 Secondly, God's moral laws have not changed from the Old Testament. Murder, adultery, robbery, fornication, gay sex, etc., are all still no-no's. 
 
 Did the person who wrote those questions in the beginning of this thread ever take the time to study the Bible long enough to notice these things? It's amazing what a little Bible Study will do.  I think that once people realize that it's other people that contaminate the Bible and abuse it, then that's when true freedom is achieved.

Personally, I wouldn't label the Bible as being 'stupid'. It's an ancient text in company with quite a few other ancient texts (Gilgamesh, Qu'ran, Hindu Vedas, etc.). In my opinion, the Bible simply reflects the notions and beliefs held by the people who wrote it. You've no doubt discovered that some folks consider the Bible to be divinely inspired and therefore inerrant. I take it that you disagree with their opinion, but I would caution you that you're not going to convince any of them by labeling their Bible as being 'stupid'.
